item.title: Cloud Gaming to Reach New Heights: GeForce NOW’s Blackwell RTX Upgrade Begins Next Week

review.headline_rewrite: Cloud Gaming to Reach New Heights: GeForce NOW’s Blackwell RTX Upgrade Begins Next Week
bullets: NVIDIA Blackwell RTX is coming to the cloud on Wednesday, Sept.
10 — an upgrade so big it couldn’t wait until a Thursday.
Don’t miss a special early GFN Thursday next Wednesday as GeForce NOW begins lighting up the globe with GeForce RTX 5080-class power streaming from the cloud.
With this upgrade, cloud gaming is about to level up.
NVIDIA Blackwell RTX brings GeForce RTX 5080-powered streaming to GeForce NOW, unlocking the highest resolutions and frame rates ever in the cloud.
Plus, the highly anticipated shooter Battlefield 6 is launching in the cloud in October.

item.title: DuckDuckGo adds access to advanced models to it subscription plan

review.headline_rewrite: DuckDuckGo adds access to advanced models to it subscription plan
bullets: Privacy-focused consumer tech company DuckDuckGo launched a subscription plan last year that bundled a VPN service, personal information removal, and identity theft restoration.
The company said Thursday that the subscription now gives users access to the latest AI models through Duck.ai without paying extra.
The Duck.ai chatbot is free to use, and users get access to models like Anthropic’s Claude 3.5 Haiku, Meta’s Llama 4 Scout, Mistral AI’s Mistral Small 3 24B, and OpenAI’s GPT-4o mini.
With DuckDuckGo’s $9.99 per month plan, users will be able to access newer models, including OpenAI’s GPT-4o and GPT-5, Anthropic’s Claude Sonnet 4, and Meta’s Llama Maverick.
“These bigger models are better at following detailed instructions, maintaining context through extended chats, and delivering deeper, more nuanced responses.
The DuckDuckGo subscription offers a way to use some of these models, but with more privacy,” the company said in a post.

item.title: Adobe to bring its video editing app Premiere to iPhones

review.headline_rewrite: Adobe to bring its video editing app Premiere to iPhones
bullets: The company said that Premier on iPhone will let users edit videos and export them without any watermarks.
And in keeping with its efforts elsewhere, Adobe is bringing AI features powered by its Firefly models to the app: Premiere on iOS will let users generate images, audio or videos using text prompts.
Premiere on iPhone will be free to use, but users will have to pay for using AI credits and cloud storage.
The company launched Photoshop for iOS in February and released a beta version of the app for Android in June.

item.title: Here’s how the Pixel’s AI zoom compares to a real 100x lens

review.headline_rewrite: Here’s how the Pixel’s AI zoom compares to a real 100x lens
bullets: In case you missed it last week among other big news items, Google shipped a phone camera with a zoom feature that uses generative AI.
That’s right: the Pixel 10 Pro comes with AI right inside the camera app that cleans up otherwise crappy digital zoom images all the way up to 100x.
The Pixel 10 Pro’s Pro Res Zoom makes those guesses with the help of generative AI.
And if we’re taking AI zoom photos, what better subject to start with than the moon?
It is asking a lot of a smartphone camera to take a picture of the moon, and Google isn’t the first phone maker to bring AI to the fight.
The Pro Res Zoom version certainly looks moon-like, but AI gives it a strange spongey texture that doesn’t look quite right — especially comparing it to the P1100’s version.

item.title: Nvidia’s RTX 5080 upgrade for GeForce Now arrives on September 10th

review.headline_rewrite: Nvidia’s RTX 5080 upgrade for GeForce Now arrives on September 10th
bullets: Nvidia announced last month that it’s planning to upgrade its GeForce Now cloud gaming service to RTX 5080 GPUs.
The upgrade will allow GeForce Now subscribers to rent what’s effectively an RTX 5080 in the cloud, with a huge 48GB of memory and DLSS 4 support.

“To celebrate, next week’s GeForce Now announcements will come a day earlier to usher in the Blackwell era of GeForce Now.”
Nvidia is also bringing back the ability to install games on GeForce Now without waiting for Nvidia to formally curate them.

item.title: DuckDuckGo's subscription now offers some of the latest chatbots from OpenAI and Anthropic

review.headline_rewrite: DuckDuckGo's subscription now offers some of the latest chatbots from OpenAI and Anthropic
bullets: Since the start of last summer, DuckDuckGo has offered a handful of AI chatbots from OpenAI, Anthropic and others directly through its browser.
And while it's mostly low-cost models like GPT-4o mini and Claude 3.5 Haiku on offer, the feature, Duck.ai, allows you to use those tools without sacrificing your privacy.
The price of the service — either $10 per month or $100 billed annually — remains unchanged, and you still get all the previous perks included in the package.

It's now simply known as the DuckDuckGo subscription, and, in addition to offering access to the company's own VPN, as well as its personal information removal and identity protection services, it allows you to use some of the latest models from OpenAI, Anthropic and Meta.
As before, any conversations you have with those chatbots through DuckDuckGo are anonymized and your data won't be used for training future systems.
"Today, we're expanding Duck.ai by giving DuckDuckGo subscribers access to more advanced AI models, covered by the same strong protections," said DuckDuckGo.
